b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:47): kinda wishes innerHTML always used the HTML serialization--even in XML DOMs
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:48): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: We do in XHTML
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:48): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: We do in XHTML
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:49): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, no, we use the HTML parser; that's wrong per spec
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:50): That's always using the HTML serialization.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:50): I know it's wrong per spec.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:50): Having a bug free impl and supporting something aren't identical, IMO
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:51): this is a fundamental flaw in the feature implementation
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:51): but whatever
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:53): "Internet Explorer web browser use drops below 60%" -- maybe that explains all the markety IE blog posts and Sylvain being cranky :p
c0a6c470e31cd9d911b5082260cdca10 (17:53): That goes without saying.

15e961ef7eb5e456a7fff39e7a744674 (18:10): does anyone have any guidance regarding source order vs the visual order? the only decent information we can find is : http://usability.com.au/resources/source-order.cfm

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:29): 15e961ef7eb5e456a7fff39e7a744674: I'd probably listen to actual usability experts, but as far as I know Google puts more weight on content earlier in the page, so having good source order can help your rank at least.

15e961ef7eb5e456a7fff39e7a744674 (18:34): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: see that's the problem, there a lot of people saying similar things, however there is a lack of any evidence unfortunately. Do you have any concrete links you could point me to?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:35): Well, that link you provided is backed up by actual usability testing.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:35): And so seems reasonably beleivable.
15e961ef7eb5e456a7fff39e7a744674 (18:40): yes but there is debate regarding the results of the testing, it would be good to have some official info from sound sources

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:40): When you say "debate", are you just referring to the fact that the results were somewhat inconclusive on the question of source order in that study, or are there actual objections to the data in that study?
15e961ef7eb5e456a7fff39e7a744674 (18:42): a bit of both really
15e961ef7eb5e456a7fff39e7a744674 (18:43): I don't have the links to hand at the moment
15e961ef7eb5e456a7fff39e7a744674 (18:44): Bruce Lawson seems to go with content first: http://www.brucelawson.co.uk/2007/navigation-or-content-first/
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (18:44): Kk, then I dunno personally.  I personally prefer content-first for organizational purposes, and from everything I've read it's neutral at worst.

15e961ef7eb5e456a7fff39e7a744674 (18:46): yeah that's the conclusion I'm coming to... the only thing that is pushing me more towards navigation first is that the majority of sites are structured that way... it's almost a standard which people expect
15e961ef7eb5e456a7fff39e7a744674 (18:46): and if there is no benefit, I'd rather stick with convention
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (18:47): why oh why did ian give in w/r/t video codecs
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (18:47): h.264 everywhere is going to be utter hell
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (18:47): i've already seen two posts calling this gif wars 2.0
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (18:48): 59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73, because he can't change anything.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:48): 59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73, there have been many comparisons with gif ever since this issue first came up
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (18:48): opera, mozilla, google are willing to implement theora in their browsers regardless of if it is mentioned in the spec.
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (18:49): and apple or microsoft are not gonna give in because of spec text.
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (18:49): especially not microsoft.
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (18:49): 59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73, html5 is more descriptive than normative
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (18:49): microsoft not giving in
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (18:49): doesnt mean we shouldnt lord it against them
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (18:50): doesnt mean we shouldnt put it in the spec
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (18:50): specs are there a model for what you ought to be doing

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:52): 59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73, the purpose of the spec is to define things that browsers will interoperably implement. It's not helpful to have the spec define a requirement that browser vendors have stated they will ignore
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (18:52): so the only time a spec is worth doing is if its unanimous?

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:55): no, decisions made in the spec certainly aren't always unanimous. But they should at least be implementable and there should at least be a willingness among vendors to implement it.

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:56): teh bottom line is, everyone knows the situation is not ideal. But trying to get the spec to mandate a specific codec for whatever reason will not help in the slightest to resolve the issues that web developers now face
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (19:01): i relent to acknowledging there is no way out, that the whole fiasco is a huge grey area.
59239043d359e06fea10867d04b58a73 (19:02): i'd like to thank binary42 for taking me to task on the legal complexities of the issue in another channel
